Award.AwardTitle: WSC Category 3 Collaborative: Impacts of Climate Change on the Phenology of Linked Agriculture-Water Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1360415 (Ball), 1360345 (Brady), 1360424 (Ortiz-Bobea), and 1360395 (Wainger). This research will create an integrated trans-disciplinary system of data-driven econometric and numerical simulation models to understand how farmers adapt to climate change and how these altered practices are processed through a watershed to affect downstream estuarine ecosystem health (e.g., water quality, hypoxia). The project approach involves simultaneous collaborative and integrated activities by three research teams: Economics and Policy, Watershed, and Estuary. The Economics and Policy Team includes agricultural and environmental economists, whose empirical models feed and constrain the simulation models that are to be developed and linked by the Watershed and Estuary Teams. The Chesapeake Water System (CWS) is used as the study site because of its rich and long-term record of data. Synthesis of these data with models will enable comparative analyses to reveal broad relationships between human and natural drivers and processes that extrapolate well to water systems worldwide. This research will advance knowledge of: 1) how climate changes influence the timing and type of agricultural practices; 2) how temporal and spatial scales of watershed models influence simulated effects on nutrient delivery; 3) how direct influences of climate change on ecosystems compare to indirect influences that cascade through the watershed; and 4) how alternative management policies - with different rules and incentives - affect farming behavior and thus ecologic health. The effort will also advance understanding of how best to link economic and policy modeling approaches and scales with those of watershed and estuary simulation, as related to maintaining water system sustainability under climate change. Agricultural models of farmer adaptation will empirically demonstrate how spatial and temporal distributions of practices are altered by climate change, allowing transformation of the modeling approach and improving the observational grounding of the models. Further, this work will advance ability to test policies aimed at managing nutrient emissions from agriculture by characterizing conditions at scales relevant for understanding adoption/compliance.

The Watershed Team will use process understanding - synthesized from data across multiple watersheds - to assess structural uncertainties in conventional models that are typically ignored in policy applications. The Estuary Team's data synthesis will search for climate-related shifts in timing and amounts of nutrient loading and use numerical simulation models to quantify effects on Bay health. The Economics and Policy Team will apply a novel state-contingent pollution-control approach that incorporates uncertainty. Through the development and linkage of these models, this project will help transform climate-change impact assessment and response, tackle basic knowledge gaps in the understanding of long-term sustainability of estuarine water systems, and develop new tools and understanding that are applicable to other water bodies influenced by agricultural land use. The areas of broader impact for this project include: 1) workforce recruitment and training; 2) transfer of tools and knowledge to environment management agencies; 3) enhanced public understanding and K-16 science education. In the first regard, the project will recruit, train and mentor 8-12 MS and PhD students toward careers in ecology, economics, hydrology, oceanography and engineering with foci on water quality, agricultural sustainability, environmental policy analysis, and climate change. Secondly, the team will continue to work very closely with investigators in USDA, USEPA, USGS, and other federal and state agencies working with the Chesapeake Bay Program to develop better integrated modeling tools for modeling support of environmental management. Interactions with the Bay management community will include regular meetings with collaborators, presentations of findings at CBP meetings and collaborative workshops. Thirdly, K-16 education will be improved through integration of products into a highly successful ongoing NSF COSEE program, including a new workshop for training 15 high school teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved four Collaborative Research teams working at Johns Hopkins University (co-PIs Ball and Harman), the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science (co-PIs Wainger, Testa, Kemp, Murray, and O'Neil) Cornell University (PI Ortiz-Bobea), and the University of Maine (PI Brady), with assistance from Va. Tech (PI Easton), Penn State University (PI Shortle), and multiple federal agencies.  Our teams explored how climate change affects the “intra-annual phenology” (seasonal  timing and amounts) of pollutant loads to receiving water through its effect on (1) farmer behavior, (2) hydrology, (3) watershed function, and (4) ecological processing, uptake, and ultimate water-quality impact of the pollutants in, by, and on estuarine receiving waters of Chesapeake Bay, as a testbed for the approach. In addition, final on-going exercises are exploring integrated effects of all of the above in a selected watershed and associated sub-tributary of the Chesapeake Bay, while also exploring potential policy actions that may mitigate the effect. In addition, a team at UMCES worked extensively with local high-school teachers to create teaching modules that are compliant with Maryland education standards and can be used by teachers to help high-school level students understand environmental management concepts relating to  this work. One module is already published on-line (at https://teachoceanscience.org/) and the second will be posted within the year.

 For the watershed and estuarine efforts, outcomes are based on work within the Chesapeake Bay and its watershed; however, farmer-response investigations studied major farming regions throughout the U.S. to develop outcomes (projections) that included Chesapeake regions. Regarding the “pollutant,” most work focused on nitrate -- an important nutrient for increasing crop yield but also a major stimulant of algae growth in receiving waters. Although other major sources of nutrients are also important to Bay cleanup and protection, project scope was limited to the agricultural sector and the ecosystem itself. 

 Within the above context, outcomes relating to farmer behavior as affected by climate (and expected climate change) are discussed in a separate Project Output Report (POR) generated at Cornell University (PI A. Ortiz-Bobea). Similarly, estuarine science aspects and the integrated application toward economic and policy endpoints will be further discussed in a POR to be posted in late 2020 by the UMCES team upon completion of the work. (Although only UMCES remains in no-cost extension with NSF, all collaborators remain heavily involved in the work through continuing support from other stakeholders.)

 In regard to the JHU-centric activities on “watershed science,” this project has significantly advanced our understanding of how landscape features and climate (particularly precipitation patterns) control the movement of water and nutrients from field to stream, and how the climate and human decision-making both affect the timing of nutrient delivery to surface waters.  It has done so in three main ways. First, this project advanced a theoretical framework for understanding and predicting hydrologic transport of water and pollutants (e.g. nitrate) at the scale of watersheds. This framework – StorAge Selection functions – is now widely used in the field.  It allows us to extract -- from hydrologic tracer and water balance data -- important needed information about the volume of water stored in the landscape and how long ago that water arrived as rainfall; these are primary controls on the storage and release of nutrients in the landscape. Second, through modeling and data analysis in several study watersheds, this project advanced our understanding of how the pathways that carry water through the landscape change with climate. In particular, the project described and explained the ‘inverse storage effect’ phenomenon, which is the observation that catchments tend to release younger water under wet conditions, and older water under dry conditions. For the study watersheds, this implies that future increases in rainfall will not lead to a ‘flushing’ of legacy nutrients stored in shallow groundwater – extra rainfall will instead tend to leave the landscapes quickly. Third, we used econometric models to project changes in the timing of planting, harvesting, and fertilizer application under climate change, and used a hydrologic model to predict the cascading effects on the export of water and nutrients from the study watershed on the Eastern Shore of the Chesapeake. This work has suggested that changes in farmer behavior in response to climate change may have effects on water and nutrient dynamics that are as large as the direct effects of the climate itself – and these effects can compound, rather than mitigate one another.

Finally, we note that project-developed modeling tools from the above-described StorAge Selection framework have been incorporated into the regional-scale  watershed model that is currently being applied by the US EPA Chesapeake Bay Program Office’s (CBPO’s) Modeling Team, as a main source of guidance for jurisdictions as they establish watershed implementation plans for meeting US EPA implementation of the Water Quality Control Act for the Chesapeake Bay watershed.
